journal-meta.journal-title: The American Journal of Sports Medicine

title-group.article-title: Clinical and Electromyographic Results of Proximal and Distal Realignment Procedures in Young Patients With Recurrent Patellar Dislocations

article-meta.aff: †Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, University Medical Center Rostock, Rostock, Germany
‡Department of Orthopaedics, Sahlgrenska Academy, University of Gothenburg, Gothenburg, Sweden

author-notes.corresp: *Peter C. Kreuz, Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, University Medical Center Rostock, Doberanerstrasse 142, 18057 Rostock, Germany (e-mail: peter.kreuz@uni-rostock.de).

permissions.copyright-holder: American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Until now, no study has been published about the electromyographic changes in the extensor apparatus after the Green procedure for proximal realignment in young patients with recurrent patellar dislocations. This electromyographic study was performed to analyze imbalances between the vastus medialis and vastus lateralis muscles after different patellar realignment procedures.

sec.title: Hypothesis:
sec.p: Surgical proximal realignment leads to electromyographic changes in the extensor apparatus of the knee and to imbalances between the vastus medialis and vastus lateralis muscles.

sec.title: Study Design:
sec.p: Cohort study; Level of evidence, 3.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: A total of 28 knees of 25 patients, with a mean age of 15 years, were treated operatively for recurrent patellar dislocations. The mean follow-up was 6.3 years. Depending on the type of surgical intervention, the patients were assigned to 3 different groups: the patients of group 1 underwent only the Green vastus medialis obliquus (VMO) advancement, group 2 was treated with a combination of the Green proximal and the Roux-Goldthwait distal realignment, and group 3 was treated with a combination of the Green proximal realignment and an additional tubercle transfer. All patients underwent clinical, radiological, and electromyographic examinations. The muscle activities of a healthy control group without patellar dislocations were used for comparison.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: A combination of the Green procedure and tubercle transfer led to significantly better clinical results and a lower number of redislocations (P < .05) compared with patients who underwent only the Green proximal realignment. While ascending or descending stairs, the ratio between the electromyographic activities of the vastus medialis and vastus lateralis muscles in groups 1 and 2 was significantly smaller compared with the control group (P < .02). Only the electromyograms of group 3 revealed a balanced extensor apparatus during loading with comparable activities of the vastus medialis and vastus lateralis muscles and no significant difference to the control group (P = .37).

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: Our electromyographic investigations showed the importance of the vastus medialis in the pathogenesis of malalignment of the extensor mechanism. The Green VMO advancement without tibial tubercle transfer is not able to balance the activities of the vastus medialis and vastus lateralis muscles and cannot be recommended for further use.

body.p: Recurrent lateral dislocations of the patella are common knee problems in which the pathophysiology is multifactorial and management is controversial. Nonoperative treatment with specific exercises for the patellar stabilizers, including strengthening of the vastus medialis muscle, often results in chronic retropatellar pain, persistent symptoms of instability, and recurrent dislocations.42 Electromyographic investigations revealed subnormal activities of the vastus medialis in all types of dislocations and similar activities of the vastus lateralis in permanent and habitual dislocations.5 Recurrent dislocations of the patella require surgery because of the increased risk of irreversible damage to the articular surface.53 Numerous surgical procedures are available for the correction of patellofemoral malalignment and pain. The surgical options include lateral retinacular release,18,20,32,57 proximal realignment,1,53 distal realignment,24,25,38 reconstruction of the medial patellofemoral ligament (MPFL),51 and tibial tubercle transfer.25 However, there have not been many studies in the literature reporting the effect of these realignment procedures on the extensor apparatus with a special focus on the functional effectiveness of the vastus medialis muscle.44

In this study, we compare the surgical technique of Green et al,29 a proximal realignment procedure with vastus medialis muscle transfer, with a combination of the Green procedure with a distal realignment or a tibial tubercle transfer. Until now, no study has been published about the electromyographic changes in the extensor apparatus after these realignment procedures. This electromyographic study was carried out to obtain a better understanding of the role played by the vastus medialis and vastus lateralis muscles in the alignment of the patella and thus in the pathogenesis of subluxation in adolescents and young patients with recurrent patellar dislocations.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: Within 8 years, 34 patients with recurrent lateral patellar dislocations underwent the Green surgical proximal realignment procedure with or without additional distal realignment to correct patellar tracking. A total of 28 knees of 25 patients (10 male, 15 female) met the inclusion criteria. The mean age was 15 years (range, 5-28 years), and the mean follow-up was 6.3 years (range, 2.3-10 years). Twelve of the 25 patients (48%) reported bilateral recurrent patellar dislocations. However, only 3 patients decided to undergo surgical treatment on both knees with an interval of 6 months. The other 9 patients with bilateral patellar dislocations treated 1 knee nonoperatively with intensive muscle training. Depending on the type of surgical intervention, the patients were assigned to 3 different groups: the patients of group 1 underwent only the Green proximal realignment procedure, group 2 was treated with a combination of the Green proximal and the Roux-Goldthwait distal realignment surgical technique, and group 3 was treated with a combination of the Green proximal realignment and an additional tubercle transfer. Details of the 3 study groups appear in Table 1.

tr.td: Age at first patellar dislocation, mean (range), y
Age at surgical intervention, mean (range), y

fn.label: a
fn.p: Depending on the type of surgical intervention, the patients were assigned to 3 different groups. The patients of group 1 were treated with the Green proximal realignment procedure, group 2 with a combination of the Green proximal and Roux-Goldthwait distal realignment, and group 3 with a combination of the Green proximal realignment and an additional tubercle transfer.

sec.title: Inclusion and Exclusion Criteria
sec.p: Included were patients between 4 and 30 years of age with recurrent patellar dislocations in spite of intensive nonoperative treatment for at least 6 months. Excluded were patients with a first patellar dislocation and patients with additional systemic diseases such as Down syndrome, Marfan syndrome, aplasia of both feet, or infantile cerebral palsy. In these patients, a reliable electromyographic investigation was not possible. Furthermore, patients with a successful exercise program and significant improvement of symptoms without any further patellar dislocations for at least 1 year were excluded from surgical treatment. Patients with a severe dysplastic trochlea of Dejour types B, C, or D19 as well as varus or valgus deformities of >5° were excluded from the study population. The position of the patella was detected by routine mediolateral, patellofemoral, and axial joint radiographs.

sec.title: Study Design
sec.p: The study was conducted to determine the efficacy of the Green proximal realignment procedure compared with a combination of proximal and distal realignment techniques at the postoperative follow-up. Furthermore, we wished to discover the postoperative recurrence rate of patellar dislocation, the clinical improvement, and the electromyographic changes in the activity of the vastus medialis muscle.

sec.title: Indications for Surgical Procedures
sec.p: Only patients with recurrent patellar dislocations who met all our inclusion and exclusion criteria were admitted to our study population. Depending on the patient’s age and radiologically determined distance between the tibial tuberosity and trochlear groove (TTTG), the patients were assigned to 3 different groups: all patients with a TTTG distance of <20 mm underwent the Green proximal realignment procedure (group 1). With a TTTG distance of >20 mm, the surgical procedure depended on the patient’s age. Immature patients underwent the Green proximal realignment and the Roux-Goldthwait procedure (group 2), and skeletally mature patients with closed epiphyseal growth plates underwent a combination of the Green vastus medialis obliquus (VMO) advancement and a tuberosity transfer (group 3).

sec.title: Surgical Procedures
sec.p: The Green proximal realignment procedure is a rearrangement of the muscular attachments to the patella.29 Its purpose is to correct the adverse effect of patellofemoral incongruence by altering the line of pull of the quadriceps muscle. Quadricepsplasty includes a lateral retinacular release and a dissection of the vastus medialis and VMO from the quadriceps tendon. Afterward, the vastus medialis complex is transferred distally and laterally to the anterior surface of the patella.29,41

An additional Roux-Goldthwait distal realignment was performed in skeletally immature patients with more than 10 patellar dislocations in their history. The technique includes a longitudinal split of the patellar tendon at the midline and a detachment of the lateral half of the tibial tubercle. The detached lateral half of the tendon is then passed beneath the intact medial half and sutured to the medial aspect of the tibia in the region of the pes anserinus tendons. This lateral half should be relocated such that the pull to the extensor mechanism is in line with the femur as the knee flexes.14,27,38,45,47

Hauser’s31 tibial tubercle transfer was performed only in skeletally mature patients with closed epiphyseal growth plates and a TTTG distance of >20 mm.51 In this technique, the insertion of the patellar tendon is freed from the tibial tubercle with a rectangular bone block and pulled medially and distally on the tibia in a prepared bed. The freed bone block of this area is placed into the former bed of the initial patellar tendon insertion. Care was taken to ensure that the extensor mechanism was in line with the long axis of the femur and that the tendon was not advanced too distally as to cause increased tension. The aim was to balance the patella to a TTTG distance of <10 mm and an Insall-Salvati index of 1.0.31

sec.title: Postoperative Follow-up
sec.p: After surgery, a splint was applied for 14 days. The patients were permitted to get out of bed on the second day, and crutch-assisted, touch-down weightbearing ambulation was prescribed for 6 weeks after the surgical procedure. After 2 weeks, the splint was replaced by a brace with a limited flexion of 60°. With normal progression, 90° of flexion was reached at 6 weeks after surgery, by which time the gait returned to normal. The patients were encouraged to perform 100 to 300 straight-leg raises each day for several months.

sec.title: Study Course
sec.p: After a mean follow-up of 6 years (range, 2-10 years), all patients underwent the same standardized evaluation progress with electromyographic, radiological, and clinical examinations using the modified Bentley score (Table 2).8,9 For this purpose, the patients had to answer standardized questionnaires; rated their results as excellent (1), good (2), fair (3), or poor (4) on a visual scale; and were examined by an orthopaedic surgeon.

tr.td: Complaints during activities of daily living

fn.label: a
fn.p: The overall score corresponds to the worst score in the 7 categories.

sec.p: The electromyographic investigation was performed with self-adhesive surface electrodes (Noraxon, Cologne, Germany) applied after shaving and washing the skin with water. The activity of the vastus medialis and vastus lateralis muscular fibers was studied simultaneously in all cases while walking and ascending and descending stairs with unvarying analytical procedures: a current of 500 μV, a graph speed of 2 cm/s, and a sweep of 100 milliseconds. Electrode positioning was standardized according to study protocols to obtain accurate and repeatable surface electromyographic signals from the VMO and vastus lateralis.50 For a patient with a height of 180 cm, the optimal innervation zone and electromyographic signal quality for the vastus lateralis are at a distance of 94 mm along a line from the superior lateral side of the patella to the anterior superior iliac spine, starting from the patella. The innervation zone of the vastus medialis is at a distance of 52 mm from the superior medial side of the patella along a line inclined to 50° with respect to the anterior superior iliac spine.50 For smaller patients, the distances were appropriately adapted.

All measured data were taken as the median value with its standard deviation. As a parameter of muscular balancing of the extensor mechanism, the activity of the vastus medialis and vastus lateralis was noted as the ratio between the vastus medialis and vastus lateralis and compared with a control group of 20 knees of 10 healthy people who lived in the same city. The group consisted of students as well as children or adolescents related to the patients. The mean age, sex distribution, and activities of daily living of the control group (mean, 16 years; range, 6-30 years; 8 male, 12 female) were comparable with those of our study group (mean, 15 years; range, 5-28 years; 11 male, 17 female) (P > .05).

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Descriptive statistics during follow-up (arithmetic mean, standard deviation, range) were calculated using standard formulas. The clinical and electromyographic results of the 3 groups with different surgical techniques were compared using an independent-samples Mann-Whitney U test and the Friedman test. Furthermore, the subjective results, as measured on a visual scale, were compared with the clinical scores by use of the Spearman correlation coefficient. All statistics were performed with SPSS (version 15.0, SPSS, Chicago, Illinois) and reviewed by an independent statistician.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Thirteen knees were treated with the Green proximal realignment procedure (group 1), 7 knees with a combination of the Green proximal and the Roux-Goldthwait distal realignment surgical technique (group 2), and 8 knees with a combination of the Green proximal realignment and an additional tubercle transfer (group 3). The age at which the first patellar dislocation occurred varied between 4 and 17 years, and the age at which patients underwent surgical intervention was between 5 and 28 years (Table 1). Our study population revealed a predominance of female patients (17 female [1 bilateral], 11 male [2 bilateral]) and the right knee (18 right, 10 left) (Table 1).

Our radiological evaluation revealed a hypoplastic patella (Wiberg type II and III) in 21 and a dysplastic patella (Wiberg type IV and V) in 6 knees.46 The Insall-Salvati ratio of the tendon to the patella was ≥1.25 in 37% of all patients.34,35 The sulcus angle was >150° in 32% of all patients,12 and the patellofemoral arc according to Ficat et al22 revealed a lateralized patella in all patients. An increased Q angle of >20° and a TTTG distance of >20 mm could be detected in 32% of all patients.2 A crossing sign (dysplastic trochlea of Dejour type A) was seen in 14% of all treated knees.19

At the postoperative follow-up, 7 of all 28 treated knees had a redislocation of the patella, and 5 patients had to undergo revision surgery (Table 3). Four patients in group 1, 2 in group 2, and 1 in group 3 suffered redislocations. Three of the 7 patients with patellar redislocations had a sports injury (2 in soccer, 1 in high jump); the other 4 dislocations occurred without trauma. Two patients avoided a further redislocation and surgical intervention by intensive exercises of the vastus medialis muscle.

fn.label: a
fn.p: A combination of the Green procedure and tubercle transfer led to significantly better results and a lower number of redislocations (P < .05) compared with patients who underwent only the Green proximal realignment.

sec.p: All patients with redislocations after the Green procedure were treated by a second surgical intervention with an additional distal realignment. One patient with a redislocation after a combined proximal and distal realignment was treated with MPFL reconstruction using the semitendinosus tendon.4,30,51 Afterward, no dislocation was reported at follow-up.

Of 20 patients who participated preoperatively in different sports activities, 2 participated in no more sports, 4 fewer, 10 identical, and 4 more sports. A combination of the Green VMO advancement with a tubercle transfer or with the Roux-Goldthwait realignment led to significantly better clinical results and a lower number of redislocations (P < .05) compared with patients who underwent only the Green proximal realignment (Table 3). The Spearman correlation coefficient between the subjective results (visual scale) and the Bentley score was 0.76 and statistically significant (P < .05).

The electromyographic investigation showed different results between groups depending on the type of surgery and type of loading on the treated knee. While walking, the ratio between the activities of the vastus medialis and vastus lateralis muscles was <1 in all groups, including the controls, showing that the vastus lateralis was generally more active. There was no significant difference between the different groups (P > .05) (Figure 1A). However, during increased loads such as ascending or descending stairs, the ratio between the activities of the vastus medialis and vastus lateralis muscles was significantly smaller in groups 1 and 2 compared with the control group (P < .02). In both groups, the activity of the vastus lateralis muscle predominated (Figure 1B and 1C). Only the electromyograms of patients in group 3 revealed a balanced extensor apparatus while ascending stairs with comparable activities of the vastus medialis and vastus lateralis muscles without any significant difference in the control group (P = .37) (Figure 1C).

caption.p: (A) Electromyogram while walking: The ratio between the activities of the vastus medialis and vastus lateralis muscles was <1 in all groups, showing that the vastus lateralis was rather more active. There was no significant difference between the different groups (P > .05). (B) Electromyogram while ascending stairs: The ratio between the activities of the vastus medialis and vastus lateralis muscles was significantly smaller in groups 1 and 2 compared with the control group (*P = .004, **P = .006, ***P = .02). In both groups, the activity of the vastus lateralis muscle predominated. Only the electromyograms of group 3 revealed a balanced extensor apparatus with comparable activities of the vastus medialis and vastus lateralis muscles (P = .37). (C) Electromyogram while descending stairs: The ratio between the activities of the vastus medialis and vastus lateralis muscles was significantly smaller in groups 1 and 2 compared with the control group (*P = .002, **P = .01, ***P = .03). In both groups, the activity of the vastus lateralis muscle predominated. Only the electromyograms of group 3 revealed no significant difference compared with the control group (P = .14).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The treatment of recurrent patellar dislocations is still a difficult problem. In our study population, 48% of all patients had bilateral patellar dislocations, and 65% were female. This corresponds to other studies that describe bilateral dislocations in 35% to 62%11,60 and an incidence for female patients between 58% and 87%.28 In all patients, nonoperative treatment based on strengthening of the quadriceps and VMO and stretching the tight lateral structures was attempted for 6 months. However, only 2 patients reported no more dislocations and reduced clinical symptoms. The other patients had further dislocations, and surgical intervention was indicated. Some authors recommend a realignment procedure in these cases as well because recurrent dislocations are associated with increased joint laxity and subsequent cartilage damage with a risk of osteoarthrosis.15 More than 200 different surgical techniques and modifications exist today.33,49,54 However, none has been shown to resolve all problems of patellar malalignment and incongruity in the patellofemoral joint.

A common aim of all procedures is to centralize the patella in the trochlear groove and to strengthen and medialize the pull of the vastus medialis muscle. Smillie55 has called the vastus medialis the “key to the knee” in recognition of its importance in moving the leg through the final 15°. A systematic review and meta-analysis in patients with anterior knee pain demonstrated a delayed electromyographic onset time of the vastus medialis relative to the vastus lateralis muscle during active tasks and reflex activities (P > .01).13 The ability of the vastus medialis to pull in an oblique direction to the patella is because of its unique anatomy, consisting of an origin on the medial soft tissue adductor longus and magnus tendon.10,17 In testing 6 normal cadaveric limbs, Goh et al26 demonstrated that the absence of VMO tension caused the patella to displace laterally (4.2 mm) and increased the load on the lateral patellar facet throughout the range of knee motion. Another in vivo model demonstrated that stimulation of the VMO muscle stabilizes medial tracking of the patella.37 There is agreement that the vastus medialis is at its most active during the last phase of extension and that it prevents lateral dislocation of the patella by resisting the subluxatory pressures created by valgus angulation of the knee and by the vastus lateralis.7,40,44

Any change, whether congenital or posttraumatic, in the muscular balance between the vastus medialis and vastus lateralis is bound to affect the patellofemoral joint, giving rise, according to the severity of the disorder, to a variety of clinical presentations, such as lateral patellar sublocation or dislocation.3 This finding seemed to be confirmed by our electromyographic investigations, which showed that the motor unit action potential of the vastus medialis of our study group was significantly lower during active extension, such as while ascending or descending stairs, compared with the control group. Surprisingly, this imbalance between the activities of the vastus medialis and vastus lateralis persisted in most of the patients who underwent only the Green proximal realignment. This may be a reason for the high number of redislocations in group 1. Furthermore, there may be problems with the patellar tilt and reorientation of the pull of the vastus medialis because the dissected vastus medialis is transferred only over the superomedial patellar surface.

In agreement with our findings, other studies have also reported only 58% of patients with good and excellent results with this technique.41 The importance of VMO muscle integrity was demonstrated in the study of Madigan et al,41 which produced poor results when the VMO muscle was released as part of the Green surgical treatment for recurrent dislocations of the patella. Loss of firm attachment to the adductor magnus tendon at the distal origin potentially weakens the strength of pull of the VMO muscle, which further reduces its dynamic stabilizing force. Ahmad et al3 underlined the importance of an intact origin of the MPFL and of the VMO muscle, which has to be reconstructed in patients with acute patellar dislocations. By suturing the VMO muscle back to the adductor magnus tendon, they purportedly restored the ability of the muscle to pull obliquely on the medial border of the patella, which provided proper dynamic backup to the static stability provided by the MPFL.3

In contrast to patients who underwent only the Green procedure, knees that had undergone proximal realignment and tubercle transfer revealed a balanced electromyographic activity between the vastus medialis and vastus lateralis muscles. The reason for this phenomenon may be the distally and laterally transferred tibial tubercle, which results in greater medialization of the patella and increased tension and better proprioception of the vastus medialis. In this context, a multicenter study showed that patients with patella alta (a higher Insall-Salvati index) had a higher risk of a complete MPFL tear than patients with a normal Insall-Salvati index (P < .05).48 This phenomenon can be explained by the mismatch between high ligament and low muscle tension.

Regarding only the results of our study population, we would favor the combination of a proximal and distal realignment procedure. Patients with this combined treatment had significantly less redislocations and better clinical results compared with patients who underwent only the Green procedure (P < .05). However, a tubercle transfer may also be associated with risks such as a nonunion and should be performed only in patients with a pathological TTTG distance of >20 mm and not simply to compensate the weaknesses of a proximal realignment technique.56 For these indications, we favor 2 techniques: the Hauser osteotomy with medialization and distalization of the tibial tubercle in patients in whom the patella is medialized and riding high (Insall-Salvati index >1.2).31 In these cases, we reduce the Hoffa fat pad to prevent an uncontrolled increase of pressure in the anterior knee compartment with the risk of chondral damage by distalization of the tuberosity. Furthermore, in the present study we have adapted the amount of distalization depending on the position of the patella in the sagittal plane. The aim was a postoperative Insall-Salvati index of 1.0.

Today, we perform the Fulkerson procedure with anteromedialization of the tibial tuberosity in patients with a normal Insall-Salvati index. We believe that additional anteriorization allows better pressure control in the anterior knee compartment and may protect cartilage. In this context, cadaveric studies have shown that the Fulkerson procedure was associated with decreased contact pressures on the lateral patellar facet and on the lateral trochlea.23,39 However, pure anteriorization according to the Maquet procedure is not able to realign the patella and cannot be recommended in the treatment of recurrent patellar dislocations.43 In contrast, Fulkerson23-25 described good results without additional proximal realignment of the vastus medialis with his combination of medialization and anteriorization of the tibial tubercle. Medialization of the tibial tubercle may have a similar effect to the Green procedure, as the VMO is tensioned concurrently. However, the muscle with its attachments and innervations remains completely untouched. Therefore, we see no more indication for the combination of a tuberosity transfer with the Green technique, which we no longer utilize as a combined or isolated procedure. The combination of tuberosity transfer and additional lateral release or medial capsular reefing is not obligatory and should be decided individually.

Studies with both isolated and combined tibial tubercle transfers have shown good clinical results without further patellar dislocations in over 90% of all patients.6,21 In contrast, patients with a normal TTTG distance, normal patellar height, and recurrent instability, with or without trochlear dysplasia, are candidates for a proximal realignment procedure.16 Trochleoplasty was not performed in our study because patients with a severe dysplastic trochlea of Dejour types B, C, and D were excluded.19 Furthermore, there is only a small amount of data with biopsies within 6 to 9 months after trochleoplasty that have shown a hyaline architecture but already minor chondral changes in the calcified layer.52 The largest study on trochleoplasty was performed in 45 knees with a follow-up of 8.3 years. Although trochleoplasty was effective in preventing future patellar dislocations, it did not stop the progression of patellofemoral osteoarthritis, and 43% had worsening of preoperative patellofemoral pain.58

The treatment of patients with a normal TTTG distance depends on the degree of instability and the quality of the medial patellar stabilizers. We reconstruct the MPFL with the gracilis tendon49 or perform the Insall realignment with lateral retinacular release, medial parapatellar arthrotomy, and medial capsular tightening with reefing of the vastus medialis by overlapping the medial flap on the patella and the quadriceps tendon by 1.0 to 1.5 cm. This leads to a homogeneous medial shift of the patella without detachment of the VMO muscle from the adductor tendon or unphysiological forces that might tilt the patella. Even if we cannot yet report about our own long-term results or electromyographic investigations after an MPFL repair or an Insall procedure, Wagner et al59 found only 2% of redislocations after a follow-up period of 12 to 24 months in patients with an MPFL repair; Insall et al33 had a 91% incidence of good and excellent results with a follow-up period of 2 to 10 years; and Scuderi et al54 reported about 81% good and excellent results for as long as 9 years. Younger patients had a better prognosis, which is attributed to less severe chondromalacia.54 Furthermore, Scuderi et al54 found a sex preference, with more excellent results in male patients. In female patients, factors such as a broader pelvis, increased femoral anteversion, and genu valgum were speculated to result in residual forces that tend to pull the patella laterally, perpetuating the symptoms. For these reasons, we have excluded patients with a valgus malalignment of >5° from our study group. In these patients, we first correct the mechanical axis, which is associated with medialization of the patella. In immature patients, we perform temporary hemiepiphysiodesis with 8 plates, and in adults, we perform femoral osteotomy, which can be combined with an additional correction of femoral rotation if necessary.36

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Our electromyographic investigations show the importance of the vastus medialis in the pathogenesis of malalignment of the extensor mechanism. The Green proximal vastus medialis realignment procedure without a tibial tubercle transfer is not able to balance the activities of the vastus medialis and vastus lateralis muscles and cannot be recommended for further use.

fn.p: The authors declared that they have no conflicts of interest in the authorship and publication of this contribution.
